description.narrative: Danmission - NGO call Lebanon 2021-2023 - Enhanced participation of youth and civil society in inclusive political and social reform processes, at the local and national levels, contribute to reducing vulnerabilities and to sustainable social cohesion in Lebanon.
FL §06.32.02.15 Other Initiatives in Asia and the Middle East

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: By 2023, 200 members of CSOs (primarily youth-based) are trained in promoting and working with equal rights, accountability, diversity and participation for peaceful pluralism and inclusive co-citizenship across geographic, religious, sectarian, social, professional, and other denominators.

By 2023, a minimum of 70 (out of the 200) CSO members, of whom attended the trainings, have made action plans for how to include the new knowledge and skills in their activities and communication on local and national levels in Lebanon.

By 2023, a minimum of 30 religiously engaged actors, throughout Lebanon, translate and formulate theology to strengthen churches, mosques, and other local faith communities’ ability to engage in the public space for promoting social cohesion and action in a sustainable manner that can continue beyond the project.

By 2023, a minimum of 30 religiously engaged actors and their constituencies in at least six geographic areas/host communities, report an increased awareness and knowledge about the role of theology and theologians (public theology) in responding to the needs, hopes and voices of the most vulnerable social groups, including refugees.

By 2023, a minimum of 11 youth-led local social cohesion initiatives are implemented by youth and social actors throughout Lebanon in six geographic areas3 (including refugee and host communities) via methods of diapraxsis.
A minimum of 50% of the 11 local social cohesion initiative applies the knowledge of rights-based issues, diversity, and inclusivity in the initiatives.
By 2023, innovation methodologies are developed and used to pioneer digital ways of developing 1) simple rights holder surveys and 2) real-time online baseline studies

By 2023, FDCD and a minimum of 15 CSOs have participated in a capacity building training on how to collect and use scientific valid data and can use it strategically in their advocacy initiatives, project programming, and learning activities.

target.value: By 2022, FDCD and a minimum of 15 youth CSOs are trained in how to collect and use scientific valid data and are able to deliver structured data for the real-time monitoring system as well as utilise data for impact change in their work.
By 2023, the baseline tool will have reached proof of concept level and is used by minimum 15 CSOs, to identify impact gaps in the project.

By 2021, a baseline tool designed to monitor levels of co-existence and the social and political reform process on a running basis has been designed and tested. The baseline tool will include the design of large-scale simple surveys for rights holder.

title.narrative: By 2023, at least four ‘social cohesion platforms and trainings’ are created by social actors/duty bearers, in six geographic areas of Lebanon, including host communities, to enable vulnerable social groups and social actors/duty bearers to reflect together and find ways of opposing dehumanizing forces and voices.

A minimum of 120 people participated in one of the four ‘social cohesion platforms and trainings’, initiated by social actors/duty bearers, and action plans are developed at each platforms and trainings, including shared reflection on how to promote justice and dignity for the most vulnerable groups.

target.value: By the end of 2022, one social cohesion platform and training is conducted in minimum three geographical areas, on the topics of 1) Women’s participation in political systems, 2) Refugee rights and responsibilities 3) Lebanese political system and youth political participation

By the end of 2023, one social cohesion platform and training is conducted in minimum three geographical areas, on the topic of advocacy and life skills. Moreover, a national conference with the title ‘Moving Ahead’ is conducted, including participants from throughout Lebanon.
There is a large gap between the duty bearers in power and the local community members and grassroots within the six geographic areas

title.narrative: By 2023, FDCD and a minimum of 30 CSOs use new innovative knowledge, data, and skills to strengthen their organisational capacity to promote the rights of the most vulnerable social groups based on scientific valid data.
By 2023, FDCD and a minimum of 15 CSOs can collect scientific valid data and use it strategically in their advocacy initiatives, project programming, and learning activities.

By 2023, a minimum of 35 social actors/duty bearers, (community, politically engaged, and religious leaders, private sector actors and institutions of democratic control), have used their voices and influence in new ways to reduce inequality and vulnerability among 10-12 communities, including refugees and host communities throughout Lebanon.

By 2023, a minimum of 75 specific cases are reported/collected from at least eight different communities throughout Lebanon, that the community members feel less vulnerable (compared to baseline) and now are able to participate and exercise co-citizen rights due to the actions of the social actors/duty bearers.

By 2023, a minimum of 200 members of civil society organisations (CSOs) (primarily youth-based) throughout Lebanon, promote and practice new social cohesion initiatives based on new knowledge and skills that contribute to a culture of shared sense of inclusive co-citizenship and peaceful living together.

By 2023, at least 200 CSOs members have adopted new skills and knowledge of social cohesion and have become political and social change agents by actively building a culture of shared sense of inclusive co-citizenship and peaceful living together in their communities and throughout Lebanon.
